poem:
The Sky Disputes  

Drifting dust,  
metal on iron,  
the hiss of air  
carves distance—  

a dance, deadly,  
in simmering heat—  
twenty-nine and two,  
to whirl away in silence.  

Scatter the lives,  
scatter the ruins,  
echoes in brass  
where the Red Sea sighs.  

The push and pull—  
unending.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "US says airstrikes against Houthis in Yemen will continue indefinitely US officials have said airstrikes launched against Yemen’s Iran-backed Houthis will continue indefinitely, after a first round on Saturday killed at least 31 people and injured up to 100 more. The strikes, which aim to punish the Houthis for their attacks against Red Sea shipping, are Donald Trump’s first such use of US military might in the region since he took power in January. Pete". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: US says airstrikes against Houthis in Yemen will continue indefinitely US officials have said airstrikes launched against Yemen’s Iran-backed Houthis will continue indefinitely, after a first round on Saturday killed at least 31 people and injured up to 100 more. The strikes, which aim to punish the Houthis for their attacks against Red Sea shipping, are Donald Trump’s first such use of US military might in the region since he took power in January. Pete
